problemStatement: Oral cancer is frequently underdiagnosed, especially in low-resource settings, due to the visual similarity between benign, precancerous, and cancerous oral lesions. Current diagnosis relies largely on manual examination, which is subjective and can result in delayed or incorrect treatment. Existing AI solutions mainly perform binary classification and fail to represent disease progression or provide explainable insights. This creates a critical need for a lightweight, progression-aware, and explainable system that can accurately identify oral lesions across multiple stages and support early clinical intervention.
solution: We propose a deep learning–based system that goes beyond conventional disease detection by performing progression-aware multiclass classification of oral lesions. Instead of only identifying whether a lesion is abnormal, the system determines the stage of disease progression across clinically relevant categories.  The model classifies oral images into four stages: Normal, Benign, Precancerous, and Cancerous, while simultaneously supporting multiple diagnostic perspectives such as Normal vs Abnormal, Precancer vs Cancer, and Benign vs Malignant.  To enhance transparency, the system incorporates Grad-CAM–based visual explanations, highlighting the regions of the image that influence predictions. This allows clinicians to visually verify model focus on lesion areas, improving interpretability and supporting informed clinical decision-making.

problemStatement: Millions of people today struggle with addictions like porn, smoking, alcohol, and social media. Not because they are weak, but because their brains have been tricked into believing these addictions help them feel better, reduce stress, or escape problems. In reality, these habits slowly destroy confidence, focus, relationships, and mental health.  Authors like Allen Carr (quit smoking) and the “Easy Peasy Way to Quit Porn” method have already proven that addiction can be beaten by changing how people think about the addiction, not by forcing willpower or restriction. These books have changed many lives and helped people break free by showing them that the addiction gives nothing and only takes. ​  But there is a big problem: people today are so used to short-term dopamine (reels, shorts, endless scrolling) that they cannot sit and read a book or remember its lessons for long. Even if they read once and feel motivated, life goes back to normal, they forget the key ideas, and the old addiction patterns return. The knowledge is powerful, but it is not reinforced daily.  So the real issue is this: we already have powerful methods to quit, but they are locked in books that people either never finish, never apply consistently, or quickly forget. There is no simple, personalized, daily system that takes these proven ideas and feeds them to the modern, distracted brain in small, engaging, consistent doses until the old brainwashing is fully broken and the person no longer wants the addiction.  Research validation:     1) Smoking: India has around 100 million smokers and over 250 million tobacco users, with both men and women affected, including school-going youth. Source : https://gsthr.org/countries/profile/ind/1/  2) Porn: India is among the top countries in porn consumption; studies show millions of adults and many young people use porn, with a significant share showing addiction-like patterns, in both men and women. Source : https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC12242039/  3) Social media: Around one-third of Indian students show social media addiction like behavior, with heavy daily use linked to anxiety, poor sleep, and lower academic performance. Source : https://sanaroohealthcare.com/social-media-addiction-and-mental-health-the-hidden-epidemic-among-indian-youth  4) Relapse is high: Across addictions, 40–60% of people relapse within 1 year, even after treatment, showing that willpower and standard methods are not enough.  Source : https://www.addictionhelp.com/recovery/statistics/  5) Debrainwashing works: Debrainwashing  methods show higher quit rates (up to ~50% long-term for smoking) by changing beliefs about the addiction instead of relying on willpower  Source : https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10540232/
solution: Our solution is a personalized addiction recovery app designed to address the three most common modern addictions: Porn Smoking Social media Instead of offering generic advice, the app adapts entirely to the user’s real struggles. On onboarding, users select one or more addictions they want to work on, and the experience is tailored accordingly.  🧠 Core Philosophy: Truth Over Illusion At the heart of the app are 1–2 minute “micro-lessons” designed for short attention spans and daily consistency. These lessons are inspired by principles from methods like Allen Carr’s approach and EasyPeasy, but rewritten in our own words and structure for today’s digital generation.  Each snippet focuses on: Exposing false beliefs behind addiction (e.g., “This calms me,” “This helps my stress,” “This makes me happy”) Showing how the addiction actually creates the pain it promises to solve Offering healthier, realistic alternatives to respond to cravings The goal is not discipline through fear, but mental clarity through truth.  Habit Building (Without Pressure) Users can choose a streak goal (e.g., 21 days, 30 days, or longer). By completing daily snippets and short reflections, they: Build consistency Unlock small, meaningful upgrades Feel progress without gamifying recovery in a shallow way The focus is growth, not guilt.   Gentle Support System On Android (and where iOS allows), users can enable a persistent, soft reminder notification — a calm signal that support is always one tap away when urges arise.   🚨 Emergency Button (Core Feature) When cravings hit, users can press the Emergency Button. The app will then: Ask how they feel right now (stressed, lonely, bored, empty, etc.) Show their own past reflections and relapse notes, reminding them how it actually felt afterward Contrast “life before addiction vs life during addiction”, using memories or photos they chose to save Display short, powerful truth lines and motivational reminders to break the craving loop This feature helps interrupt impulsive behavior using self-awareness, memory, and emotional grounding.   🤝 Community & Shared Growth Users can optionally join a supportive community space where they can: Share daily reflections Post streak updates Be honest about relapses Reactions are simple and supportive (e.g., “Respect”, “I relate”), keeping the space safe and non-judgmental. For those who want more engagement, there’s an optional recovery-only vertical feed (similar to reels), limited strictly to: Wins Lessons Real recovery stories This allows mindful scrolling without exposure to toxic or addictive content.   🌱 The Bigger Goal This app isn’t about forcing control or willpower. It’s about changing what people believe about their addictions  until the desire itself slowly weakens and fades.   We’ll continuously refine the experience through real user feedback and expert input, while staying true to this core philosophy: Freedom comes from clarity, not suppression.  Feasablity, Innovation, Creativity these 3 aspects we want to expand and work on.

problemStatement: Predicting Accidents Before They Happen Road accidents remain one of the leading causes of injury and death worldwide. While modern safety systems focus on detecting accidents or reacting in real time, the majority of accidents are actually preceded by days or weeks of ignored near-misses, risky driving patterns, fatigue, and behavioral degradation. Current driver-assistance systems: React only at the moment of danger Depend heavily on expensive vehicle hardware Fail to identify long-term behavioral risk trends As a result, drivers receive warnings too late, after unsafe habits have already formed. There is a critical gap for an intelligent, software-first system that can: Analyze driving behavior over time Identify subtle near-miss patterns and risk escalation Warn drivers before an accident becomes inevitable The challenge is to design a system that works without specialized hardware, is scalable, and can evolve from mobile-based deployment to full vehicle integration. 🎯 Objective Build an AI-powered accident prevention system that: Learns from driving behavior trends rather than crash events Predicts rising accident risk days in advance Provides proactive, preventive warnings to drivers This system should demonstrate how behavioral intelligence can shift road safety from reaction to prevention. 🌍 Impact A successful solution could: Reduce accidents caused by fatigue, distraction, and stress Enable early intervention instead of emergency response Create a scalable safety layer deployable on phones, vehicles, and fleets.
solution: AI-Driven Accident Prevention System We propose a software-first AI system that prevents road accidents by predicting rising accident risk days before a crash occurs, instead of reacting at the moment of danger. The core idea is to treat accidents not as sudden events, but as the final outcome of repeated near-miss behaviors such as late braking, aggressive acceleration, micro-swerving, and fatigue-driven inconsistency. 🧠 How the Solution Works 1️⃣ Behavioral Data Ingestion The system ingests driving behavior data such as: Braking intensity Acceleration and jerk patterns Swerving and sharp turns Frequency of risky maneuvers over time For the hackathon demo, this data is simulated or replayed, representing realistic driving sessions over multiple days. 2️⃣ Feature Extraction & Trend Analysis Raw motion data is converted into behavioral risk features, including: Sudden braking spikes Reaction delay indicators Driving smoothness variance Near-miss frequency trends Instead of evaluating isolated events, the system analyzes behavioral drift over time. 3️⃣ Risk Intelligence Engine (ML Layer) An anomaly-detection and trend-based ML model learns: What “normal driving behavior” looks like How risk patterns escalate gradually When the driver’s behavior deviates toward danger The model outputs a Driver Risk Score (0–100) that evolves across days, not seconds. 4️⃣ Preventive Warning System When the system detects a consistent upward risk trend, it triggers a pre-accident warning, such as: “Braking reaction time has worsened by 30% over the last 4 days” “Near-miss frequency increasing on evening routes” These alerts are preventive, not reactive — issued before any accident occurs.

This creates serious problems: loss of privacy, risk of misinterpretation, delays, uneven quality of support, and in many cases, an unfair assessment of the student’s real knowledge.  Even beyond disability, traditional pen-and-paper exams are a rigid way of testing understanding. Many students are better at explaining ideas by speaking rather than writing long answers under pressure.
solution: We propose a secure, offline-first examination system that allows students to take exams using voice and simple physical controls instead of writing. It is designed for people who cannot write with their hands, visually impaired users, and anyone who prefers spoken responses. The student application can run on desktops, tablets, or mobile devices and is delivered in a containerized form with all required components included. Before the exam, it downloads questions and settings from the server, then switches into a locked exam mode and runs fully offline, allowing students to listen to questions, answer by speaking, repeat, navigate, and submit using buttons or voice commands.  All responses are recorded as audio and converted into text locally, with both stored securely on the device during the exam. Once the exam is finished and internet access is restored, the complete exam data is uploaded to the backend for evaluation. The system supports two user roles: students who take exams through the client app, and administrators who use a separate interface to create exams, review answers, listen to recordings, and assign or verify marks, each through their own secure APIs and data stores.  The backend runs on Google Cloud services to ensure reliability, scalability, and data security. Standard exam-proctoring and software security practices such as encrypted communication, activity logging, and controlled access are followed. By removing the need for human scribes and enabling offline, accessible, voice-based exams, the platform improves fairness, protects privacy, and simplifies exam management for institutions.

problemStatement: There are many diseases that are not diagnosed until after symptom onset, and many diseases were diagnosed many years after their inception; however, as a result of complex datasets containing enormous amounts of data, including biomarkers, diagnosis of rare diseases, and distress to the patient (specifically those who cannot communicate their needs due to injury or critically ill status), they will frequently go undetected.
solution: The healthcare system is generating vast amounts of medical-related information every day. Examples of generated data include the patient's vital sign level monitoring and interpretation (i.e., ECGs, EEGs, etc.), their movement patterns (e.g., gait analysis), the patient's facial expression (facial cues), clinician-supplied clinical notes from doctors, and the patient's long-term health record (i.e., the patient history database).  Currently, no system exists to scan the clinical record to identify emerging medical issues. Most diseases will present with very minimal biological change in the first stage of development, meaning they cannot be identified by a normal physician's examination alone. This is particularly true of rare diseases that can mimic the signs and symptoms of a common disease. Patients suffering from such misdiagnoses will have prolonged suffering due to repeated misdiagnoses and mismanagement of their health condition. This issue is compounded where the patient has no ability to verbally communicate their pain or distress, such as a patient located in an ICU, infant, elderly patient or a patient experiencing neurological impairment. Physicians will often need to rely on detecting delayed or incomplete signs of pain or distress after the patient's medical symptoms have worsened, or complications of illness and/or injury have materialized.  There is currently no existing system available to continuously build on a comprehensive long-term patient data set to find hidden signatures of potential diseases and correlate obscure combinations of signs and/or symptoms.
